DOC.HEAD: Military Says Re-establishing Law and Order Top Priority
Eds: This story was filed by reporters in a pool taken to Panama by the Pentagon.
DOC.TEXT: Re-establishing law and order in Panama is the next objective of the U.S. military but the capture of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noreiga remains a priority, a top military planner said Thursday. ``As long as Noriega is floating around, there are going to be some people who will not accept'' the government of President Guillermo Endara, said Lt. Col. Bill Bennett. ``We want to capture this guy and get him to Miami,'' Bennett said. ``There are ongoing efforts to locate General _ I'm sorry, Mr. _ Noriega.'' Bennett, chief of contingency plans for the U.S. Southern Command in Panama, said he could not estimate the strength of remaining forces loyal to Noriega but that they remain mostly in outlying towns where U.S. troops have yet to go. ``We've got to re-establish law and order throughout Panama City,'' Bennett said. The plan, he said, is to identify leaders who will be loyal to the Endara government and then get a Panamanian police force in action. ``We are interested in doing what the Endara government will (need to) succeed,'' Bennett told reporters. There are about 1,500 U.S. military police already in Panama with another 1,500 en route to ``help with law and order,'' Bennett said. Bennett predicted that more Panamanian military units that ``have been sitting on the fence'' will soon support the Endara government. ``But that is where the capture of Noriega does become important,'' he said. ``We don't want to give them any sort of cause to rally to the other side.''
